Award.AwardTitle: Reducing Intergroup Conflict Using a Belief Manipulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Ending long-standing conflicts is an urgent global challenge. Although intractable conflicts develop an air of inevitability over time, these conflicts are initiated and maintained by people; therefore, changing people's hearts and minds is a critical step for resolving such conflicts. The present research evaluates a new theory-based intervention designed to promote more productive emotions and attitudes in the context of an ongoing intractable conflict. The proposed project extends preliminary work by this research team, which showed that teaching in-group members that groups do not have a fixed nature (an incremental belief about groups) increased favorable attitudes toward the opposing group and, in turn, fostered greater willingness to engage in major compromises that could lead to peace. In the current project, the researchers will for the first time examine the longer term effects of this belief-based intervention in a societal context in which in-group participants are routinely exposed to negative information about the out-group. The researchers will compare this belief-based intervention to both a Perspective Taking Intervention (a common conflict resolution strategy) and a Coping Control Intervention. Before participants are randomly assigned to one of the three interventions (and then again immediately after and six months later), attitudes and emotions toward the out-group will be assessed, along with favorability toward conciliatory actions. The study design will allow an examination of the durability of the effects of each of these three intervention conditions, as well as their influence across ideological sub-groups as they confront real world conflict-related events. Importantly, the focal intervention introduces a novel way of promoting conflict resolution, in that there is no attempt to create interactions, familiarity, empathy or perspective-taking between members of conflicting groups. Instead, the focus is on promoting a change in mindset. This research will have a broader impact on society by testing a novel approach to conflict resolution that does not involve the logistical problems associated with other interventions, such as bringing parties in conflict together or running the risk of engendering resistance by explicitly trying to teach hostile groups in intractable conflicts to empathize with each other. If successful, this new belief-based approach can be disseminated easily and broadly, and can work for people with a variety of ideological stances and cultural characteristics. This approach has relevance to a large number of intra-national and international conflicts, and to efforts aimed at preventing future conflicts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant examined a new theory-based intervention designed to promote more positive and less negative emotions and attitudes, as well as greater support for conciliation, in the context of intractable conflicts. This intervention is grounded in the view that participants who are taught that groups have a malleable nature (an “incremental” belief that groups can change over time) will exhibit more positive and less negative emotions toward the outgroup as well as greater conciliatory attitudes and actions than participants who do not receive this incremental belief intervention.

 

To test this idea, 510 Jewish Israeli citizens were recruited from communities throughout Israel and randomly assigned to one of three conditions in which they learned a) that people and groups do not have a fixed, inherent nature but can change (Incremental Intervention), b) how to take the perspective and understand the viewpoints and motivations of the Palestinians (Perspective Taking control Intervention), or c) a series of coping skills for dealing effectively with social conflict (Coping Control Intervention). Participants’ emotions toward Palestinians were assessed, along with attitudes toward conciliatory actions before and immediately after the intervention, as well as at two-week, two-month, and six-month follow-ups. We predicted that the Incremental Intervention would produce durable change in emotions, attitudes, and the desire for conciliatory actions across the political spectrum, even among participants who hold more radical, right-wing positions. The Perspective Taking Intervention was expected to have short-term effects, since taking the other side’s perspective is challenging when the outgroup appears not to reciprocate. Both conditions were expected to be more effective than the Coping Control Intervention.

 

Results indicated that participants in the Incremental and Perspective Taking conditions expressed stronger positive emotions (hope), weaker negative emotions (fear, anger, hatred), stronger positive attitudes (trust, de-legitimization), and stronger desire for conciliatory actions compared to the Coping Control intervention. Furthermore, comparing the long term effects of the Incremental and the Perspective Taking conditions suggested a rebound to the pre-workshop levels in the Perspective Taking condition but sustained positive results in the Incremental condition (e.g., compared to other conditions, Incremental Intervention participants transferred more money to a Palestinian confederate in a trust game administrated at six months post-intervention).

 

There are several notable broader impacts for the project. One impact is the dissemination of findings among the academic community (through presentations, published reports, and a conference held July, 2016 at Stanford) and the public (via mass media). A second impact is that this research brought to the fore a novel approach to conflict resolution that does not involve the logistical problems of bringing conflicting parties together. It also avoids the resistance inherent in approaches that explicitly try to teach groups in intractable conflicts to empathize with each other. It can thus be disseminated more easily and broadly, and can be applied in contexts in which explicit efforts to reduce conflict may provoke resistance.

  

One publication has already been produced under this award (Goldenberg et al., 2016), receiving positive attention both in the research worlds and in the popular media. A second paper is currently under review and two other papers are in preparation. The research data from this project will be deposited with the digital repository of the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) to ensure that the research community has long-term access to the data.
